questions.question: I don’t like meat but my wife ………………..
questions.description: We use the auxiliary in structures like these.

questions.question: If you studied hard, you ………………………… an A grade.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: What a charming girl …………………………!
questions.description: In exclamations, the auxiliary goes after the subject.

questions.question: It is ……………………. dark that I cannot see anything.
questions.description: Too and very cannot be followed by a that-clause.

questions.question: The baby is ……………………… young to walk.
You are ………………………. to know better.
questions.description: When enough modifies an adjective, it goes after that adjective.

questions.question: ………………………. brilliant idea!
questions.description: We use what a before a singular countable noun.

questions.question: …………………………. clever you are!
questions.description: In exclamations we use how before an adjective without a noun.

questions.question: If you ……………………….. the dog, it may bite you.
questions.description: In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will/can/may + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If you had gone to university, you ………………………….. a better job more easily.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would / could + have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If we …………………………. now, we could be there in time.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: My brother does not like sweets. ……………………. do I.
questions.description: Negative additions to negative remarks are made with nor/neither + auxiliary + subject
